Authors:
Mun Hua Tan, Han Ming Gan, Huan You Gan, Yin Peng Lee,
Larry J Croft, Mark B Schultz, Adam D Miller, Christopher M Austin
Title:
Comprehensive transcriptome of the Australian freshwater
crayfish species, Cherax quadricarinatus (Decapoda: Parastacidae).
Keywords:
Freshwater crayfish; Genomics; Phylogenetic analysis;
Pancrustacea; Cellulase
Abstract:
We contribute to the molecular resources and understanding
of the commercial and invasive Australian freshwater crayfish species,
Cherax quadricarinatus (Decapoda: Parastacidae), through deep sequencing
of its transcriptome from the heart, kidney, hepatopancreas, central
nerve cord and testis tissues. Bioinformatics analyses involving a
cluster assembly approach yielded one of the highest quality
transcriptome assemblies for a decapod crustacean to date. Taking
advantage of these new genetic resources, we first use these data to
explore phylogenomic relationships among crustacean species for which
suitable genomic and transcriptomic information is available. We then
examine the origin and evolution of endogenously-transcribed cellulase
genes in C. quadricarinatus, to provide new insights into controversial
issues regarding the nutritional biology of crayfishes. A total of
206,341,872 reads with an average read length of 80 bp were generated
from sequencing the transcriptomes from the heart, kidney,
hepatopancreas, nerve and testis tissues. The assembled transcriptome
contains a total of 44,525 transcripts, but only 18.75% aligned to other
crustacean proteins in the non-redundant database as first hit.
Phylogenetic analysis of a supermatrix, optimized for information
content representing 25 species and 228,681 amino acid positions, using
both maximum-likelihood and Bayesian methods produced trees with good
support for most nodes. Based on HMM profiles, we identified multiple
copies of putative digestive enzyme proteins belonging to two glycosyl
hydrolase families (GH9 and GH5), most of which have not been previously
identified. We describe a comprehensive C. quadricarinatus transcriptome
and infer crustacean phylogenetic relationships consistent with recent
studies supporting complex interrelationship between crustaceans and
hexapods. Subsequent identification of putative digestive enzyme
proteins supports the notion of endogenous enzyme production in
crayfishes whilst revealing a surprising level of evolutionary
diversification of these proteins in a crustacean species.
